questions.text: In adults, which of the following is greater in the pulmonary circulation compared to the renal circulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Blood flow rate

The pulmonary circulation receives 100% of the cardiac output, whereas the kidneys receive 22-23% of the cardiac output, therefore, the blood flow rate is higher in the pulmonary circulation as compared to renal circulation. 

As part of the systemic circulation, renal circulation has higher vascular pressure, including both arterial pressure and capillary hydrostatic pressure. The capillary oncotic pressures in the renal and pulmonary circulations are essentially equal.

questions.text: Growth hormone secretion is likely to be suppressed in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Acute hyperglycemia

Hypoglycemia is a potent stimulus for GH secretion. Acute hyperglycemia will decrease GH secretion. GH secretion is elevated in acromegaly and gigantism. Deep sleep (NREM stages III, IV) and exercise are stimuli that increase GH secretion.

questions.text: Physiological level of which of the following hormones can cause a decrease in gastric emptying?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cholecystokinin

CCK is the only GI hormone that decreases gastric emptying under normal physiological conditions. Gastrin, secretin and GIP can inhibit gastric emptying when pharmacological doses are administered experimentally.

questions.text: The volume- pressure curves in the figure given below were obtained from a normal subject and a patient with pulmonary disease. Which abnormality is likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Emphysema

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in transpulmonary pressure; compliance is equal to the slopes of the volume- pressure relationships shown in the figure. 

The patient’s volume- pressure curve denotes an increase in lung compliance. Emphysema is associated with increased lung compliance. 

Asbestosis and tuberculosis are associated with deposition of fibrous tissue in the lungs which decreases the compliance. Kyphosis causes restriction in lung expansion decreasing the lung compliance.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with increased cardiac output?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Moderate anemia

Moderate anemia will cause an arteriolar dilatation, decreasing the TPR and increasing cardiac output. 

Increased venous compliance decreases venous return decreasing the cardiac output. Cardiac tamponade and surgically opening the chest will effectively weaken the heart and thus decrease cardiac output.

questions.text:
Regarding drug therapy for rheumatoid arthritis and gout, find out the false and true statements

A.	Infliximab is contraindicated in moderate to severe heart failure patients

B.	Azathioprine needs dosage adjustment when given with febuxostat

C.	Tocilizumab targeting against CD20 receptor on B cell

D.	Colchicine safe in renal but not in hepatic failure
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Infliximab is the TNF alpha blocker – contraindicated in TB, HBV and moderate to severe heart failure patients

Azathioprine is inactivated by xanthine oxidase enzyme, so this drug will be elevated when given along with xanthine oxidase inhibitors like allopurinol and febuxostat

Tocilizumab targeting against IL- 6

Colchicine is unsafe both in hepatic and in renal failure

questions.text: Which one of the following is the IL- 11 analogue?

Everolimus is an inhibitor of mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR)

Basiliximab is a chimeric mouse-human monoclonal antibody to the α chain (CD25) of the IL-2 receptor of T cells. It is used to prevent rejection in organ transplantation, especially in kidney transplants

Canakinumab (INN), , is a medication for the treatment of systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (SJIA) and active Still's disease, including adult-onset Still's disease (AOSD). It is a human monoclonal antibody targeted at interleukin-1 beta. It has no cross-reactivity with other members of the interleukin-1 family, including interleukin-1 alpha

questions.text: A 29-year-old NRI reports to the causality with complaints of fevers, diarrhea. abdominal pain, and skin rash for 2 days. He feels fatigued and has lost his appetite. On further questioning, he says that he returned from his missionary trip to Brazil last week. He is excited as he talks about his trip. Besides a worthy clinical experience, he also enjoyed local outdoor activities, like swimming and rafting. His past medical history is insignificant. The blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg and the pulse is 100/min. On examination, there is a rash on the legs. The rest of the examination is normal. Choose the correct diagnostic stage of the pathogen responsible for this condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Spined egg

•  Schistosomiasis is a tropical disease that occurs following an Schistosomiasis infection with parasitic worms (flukes) known as schistosomes. 

•  Schistosomiasis is also called snail fever. 

•  These worms are endemic to Africa, South America, the Caribbean, the Middle East, and Asia. 

•  Schistosomes are parasites that inhabit freshwater snails. 

•  Complications arise due to immunologic reactions toward trapped eggs of schistosomes in various tissues. 

•  The eggs reach the skin. brain, muscles, adrenal glands, and eyes.

•  Spined eggs excreted in stool and urine (Exclusive for S. hematobium) is the diagnostic stage of the infection

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with unremitting diarrhea for the past 2 weeks. He describes his bowel movements as watery, non—bloody, foul—smelling, and greasy. He also has cramping abdominal pain associated with the diarrhea. He says that his symptoms started right after he returned from a father—son camping trip to the mountains. His son has similar symptoms. A stool sample is obtained, and microscopic analysis is significant for the findings shown in the image below. Choose the correct disease caused by this pathogen.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Megaloblastic anaemia

  • Image and case scenario describes Giardia lamblia / G. intestinalis.
  • It causes giardiasis – Steatorrhea.
  • Interfere with absorption of Vit B12 and leads to Megaloblastic anaemia / pernicious anaemia,
  • Treatment – Metronidazole/ tinidazole.

questions.text: A 4—year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to a peeling erythematous rash on his face, back, and buttocks which started this morning. Two days ago, his skin was extremely tender and within 24 hours progressed to desquamation. She also says that, for the past few weeks, he was very irritable and cried more than usual during diaper changes. The patient is up to date on his vaccinations and has been meeting all developmental milestones. On physical examination, his epidermis separates from the dermis by gentle lateral stroking of the skin. Systemic antibiotics are prescribed, and adequate fluid replacement is provided. Which of the following microorganisms most likely caused this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Staphylococcus aureus

•  Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) is considered a pediatric emergency as it can quickly progress to sepsis and shock. 

•  This disease is most common in children under 5 years old. 

•  It starts initially as painful erythematous skin usually associated with fever, malaise, and irritability followed by desquamation 24—48 hours later. 

•  Nikolsky sign, the separation of the epidermis by gentle lateral stroking of the skin, is often positive 

•  Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is exotoxin mediated. 

•  The exfoliative toxin produced by coagulase positive Staphylococcus aureus

questions.text: A 21-year-old man comes to the OPD with a lesion on his penis. He noted a painful ulcer on the right side of the penis 4 days ago and it has progressively increased in size since then. The patient has had no dysuria, hematuria, or penile discharge. He is a PLHIV and sexually active. The patient currently takes no medications. He appears comfortable and is afebrile. On genitourinary examination, there is a 1.5-cm ulceration on the right side of the base of the penis; this lesion is very tender and soft; has irregular, ragged borders; and is covered with grey exudate. There is no penile discharge. There is a palpable, tender, enlarged inguinal lymph node in the right groin. The examination is otherwise unremarkable. Gram stain of the scraping of the ulcer Shown in the image. Choose the correct etiological agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hemophilus ducreyi

  • It’s a case of Chancroid caused by H. ducreyi.
  • Gram stain – School of fish / Tram track appearance.
  • Gram-negative bacterium transmitted through sexual contact. 
  • It presents as one or more deep, painful ulcers with ragged borders that are associated with a grey exudate and inguinal lymphadenopathy. 
  • On Gram stain, the organism appears as curved, gram-negative rods, often in a clumping pattern.

questions.text: A previously healthy 8-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with fever and mouth pain that began yesterday. He has consumed an adequate amount of fluids but refuses to eat due to the pain. The patient has no medical problems and takes no medications. Physical examination reveals swollen gums and vesicular, inflamed lesions on his hard palate and lips as shown in the image. He has enlarged and tender cervical lymph nodes. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

DNA virus, double-stranded, enveloped

  • Primary herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV—1) infection is characterized by the gingivostomatitis (vesicles on the lips and hard palate, fever, lymphadenopathy) seen in this young patient. 
  • Recurrent HSV—1 infection causes lip lesions that are typically less severe due to existing cellular and humoral immunity from the prior infection.
  • HSV—1 and other herpesviruses are enveloped and possess double-stranded DNA genomes.
  • Transmission is usually by direct contact with infected oral secretions or lesions. Inoculation occurs on mucosa or skin where the vims replicates rapidly in the host cell nucleus and causes abnormal cell division, resulting in intranuclear inclusion bodies and muti nucleated giant cells visible on Tzanck smear. 
  • The vesicular lesions result from cell lysis and necrosis as well as tissue destruction, inflammation, and fluid accumulation between the dermis and epidermis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old previously healthy man comes to the emergency department due to fever, malaise, anorexia, and painless swelling of the left eye. His symptoms began after a month-long anthropology trip to a rural village. During his stay, he lived in an adobe house with a thatched roof and unnetted windows and doors. Physical examination shows left-sided periorbital swelling and conjunctival erythema with no discharge. The remainder of the physical examination, including right eye examination, shows no abnormalities. Giemsa-stained peripheral blood smear is shown in the image. What is the mode of transmission of this pathogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Stercorian

  • Chagas disease is a vector-borne protozoan illness caused by T. cruzi.
  • Unilateral periorbital edema with ptosis.
  • Risk is greatest in those with long-term domestic exposure to the Triatomine bug / reduviid bug , which nests in thatched roofingand the cracks of adobe or unfinished brick. 
  • Transmission occurs when the bug feeds on human blood during the night and defecates the underlying pathogen, Trypanosoma cruzi, into the bite wounds.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with worsening somnolence, lethargy, and decreased urine output. The patient has no prior medical conditions but had abdominal cramps and diarrhea several days ago that later became frankly bloody. Physical examination shows mild pallor and moist mucous membranes. Laboratory studies reveal elevated blood urea nitrogen and serum creatinine levels. Peripheral blood smear shows fragmented erythrocytes. This patient's condition is most likely related to consumption of which of the following foods?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Undercooked beef

  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is a major cause of acute renal failure in children. 
  • It is characterized by the triad of renal insufficiency, thrombocytopenia, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. 
  • Most cases occur due to underlying enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli(EHEC) infection, particularly with the 0157 : H7 serotype.
  • EHEC is a gram-negative, enteric rod that acquires the ability to produce Shiga toxin from a lysogenic bacteriophage. 
  • Shiga toxin enters the cytosol of host cells and cleaves a protein motif off the 60s ribosomal subunit, which irreversibly halts host protein synthesis and causes cell death
  • The primary reservoir for EHEC is the gastrointestinal tract of healthy cattle. 
  • Humans primarily acquire the organism after consuming contaminated, undercooked beef. Because low infectious closes (10-100 organisms) are required for disease, meatpacking facilities that process high volumes of ground beef are an important source of outbreaks.

questions.text: A 58-year-old asymptomatic woman comes to the OPD for a health check-up prior to starting volunteer work at a hospital. She has a history of hypothyroidism and takes levothyroxine. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Her examination findings are unremarkable. During a laboratory test, her white blood cells are incubated with mycobacterial antigens. Compared to the control, a large amount of interferon-gamma is detected in her blood sample. Which of the following cell types is most directly responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

T lymphocytes

  • Interferon-gamma (lFN-y) activates macrophages, increases major histocompatibility complex expression, and promotes T helper 1 lymphocyte (Th1) differentiation. 
  • It is produced primarily by activated T lymphocytes and natural killer cells and is critical in immunity against viral and intracellular bacterial infections. 
  • lFN-y release assays (lGRAs) test for latent tuberculosis infection (LTBl) by measuring the response of T lymphocytes when exposed to antigens unique to Mycobacterium tuberculosis. 
  • Similar to tuberculin skin tests (eg, purified protein derivative), lGRAs measure cell-mediated immunity.
  • lGRAs have comparable sensitivity and specificity to tuberculin skin tests, but advantages include their lack of cross-reactivity to the Bacille Calmette—Guérin (BCG) vaccine and that a follow-up visit is not required.
  • Neither skin tests nor IGRAs can be used to distinguish active tuberculosis from LTBI

questions.text: Each of the following statements concerning Candida albicans is correct except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Candida albicans is transmitted primarily by respiratory aerosol

  • Candida is endogenous – Part of normal flora.
  • As a member of the normal flora, C. albicans is already present on the skin and mucous membranes. 
  • In addition to the skin, C. albicans is found throughout the gastrointestinal tract (especially the mouth and esophagus) and in the vagina. 
  • Thrush in the newborn is the result of passage through a birth canal heavily colonized by the organism. 
  • The presence of C. albicans on the skin predisposes to infections involving instruments that penetrate the skin, such as needles (intravenous drug use) andindwelling catheters.
  • It is often found in the urine of patients with indwelling urinary (Foley) catheters.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of pediatric dysphonia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Vocal fold nodules

Ref: Read the text below.

Sol:-

•	Vocal fold nodules are the most common cause of pediatric dysphonia (5% to 40%).

•	Patients generally present with a harsh breathy voice, and they often have limited pitch range. 

•	These children may be either heavy voice users or vocal abusers who frequently scream and yell.

questions.text:
65-year-old diabetic patient complains of a 2-day history of left jaw pain followed by rapid onset of neck swelling(Fig A).

On examination, he looks unwell and is pyrexial. There is no stridor but he is finding it difficult to talk due to limited mouth opening. Select the most appropriate diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Submandibular abscess

Ref: Read the text below.

Sol:-

•	This is Ludwig’s angina. It is characterized by a rapidly progressive cellulitis of the soft tissues of the neck and floor of the mouth. With progressive swelling of the soft tissues and elevation and posterior displacement of the tongue, the most life-threatening complication of Ludwig's angina is airway obstruction. The submandibular space is the primary site of infection. This space is divided by the mylohyoid muscle into a submaxillary space inferiorly and sublingual space superiorly.

•	In 90% of cases the cause is odontogenic in origin, primarily from the second and third molars as their roots penetrate the mylohyoid ridge such that any abscess or dental infection has direct access to the submandibular space, parapharyngeal space and retropharyngeal space, thereby potentially encircling the airway.

•	Other causes include penetrating injuries and mandibular fractures.

•	Airway management is the foundation of treatment for patients with Ludwig's angina. The decision to secure the airway relies on clinical judgment and experience. Intravenous antibiotics (combinations of penicillin, clindamycin and metronidazole are typically used) should be started as soon as possible. Once the airway is deemed to be secure the neck should be imaged. Contrast enhanced computed tomography (CT) is the most frequently used modality and can identify abscess formation that occurs in two thirds of patients.

•	Any abscess should be drained once the airway is secure. The source of the infection (e.g. infected tooth/teeth) should also be addressed.

questions.text: Following statements about Barlow’s syndrome are true except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Mitral Valve Prolapse/Barlow’s syndrome /Click murmur syndrome is a myxomatous degeneration of the cardiac valves. It predominantly affects the Mitral Valve (Posterior leaflet) and in 10-15% may affect the Tricuspid valve also. The degenerated MV becomes redundant and may allow a jet of MR. 

MVP is defined as bulge of the MV >=2 mm beyond the annulus of the mitral valve. Usually lesions between 2-5mm are symptomatic and unlikely to progress to MR and require no treatment. Lesions > 5mm valve thickness are classical. Patients having asymmetric thickening of the leaflets are likely to progress to MR and are associated with increased risk of IE requiring prophylaxis.

questions.text: 10 yr boy is admitted with infective endocarditis. On examination Gibson’s murmur is audible. Mother gives H/O Rubella infection during pregnancy. The most likely diagnosis in this case is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

PDA – is persistence of the ductus arteriosus beyond 1 month of age. It is seen more commonly in children born in high altitude, prematurity and maternal rubella. 

The ductus is kept patent by PG synthesis which is inhibited after birth due to increasing oxygenation in pulmonary vessels. It produces a Continuous murmur/Train in 
Tunnel murmur/ Gibson’s murmur which is best auscultated in the first ICS on left side (Gibson’s area). 

Common teratogenic conditions include:

1.	Rubella- PDA, Pulmonary A Stenosis

2.	Alcohol - VSD

3.	Phenytoin- PS

4.	Thalidomide- Phocomelia

5.	Lithium - Ebstein anomaly

questions.text: A 32-year-old female with past history of rheumatic fever (20 years back) that was treated with antibiotics. She is asymptomatic. Her physical examination shows a heart rate of 70 beats per minute with a blood pressure of 122/77 mm Hg. She has no jugular venous distention. Her lungs are clear. She has a regular rate and rhythm with a loud S1. A soft early diastolic rumble is heard at the apex with an opening snap after S2. There is wide separation between A2 and the opening snap. No peripheral edema is present. Which of the following is the most appropriate next recommendation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The patient’s examination is consistent with rheumatic mitral stenosis. Severity of her mitral stenosis is mild based on her examination, and she is asymptomatic. Current guidelines recommend antibiotic prophylaxis for secondary prevention in patients with rheumatic fever and carditis. Diuretic therapy is recommended for patients with symptoms of heart failure.

questions.text: 25-year-old male presents to an ENT clinic with sensorineural deafness. He has no history of ear infection or any illicit drug use in the past. Systemic examination reveals normal Blood pressure. He complains of recurrent loin pain in the past with hematuria. His renal function test reveals elevated Creatinine and urine examination revealed eumorphic RBC’s. other systemic examination is normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Barrter’s syndrome

Barrter’s syndrome is an autosomal recessive inherited channelopathy of the renal tubules causing inhibition of the Na-K-2Cl ATPase pump. This leads to dehydration and can cause renal dysfunction due to tubular defect. It is associated with increased risk of renal calculi due to hypercalciuria. The same pump maintains endolymph concentration in the cochlea and leads to sensorineural deafness.

Renal dysfunction with deafness in a young male can mimic Alport’s syndrome. But Alport’s syndrome causes recurrent hematuria (dysmorphic) due to glomerulonephritis and associated with Lens defect.

questions.text: 55-year-old male suffering from DM and HTN for 7 years underwent a routine ECG. ECG revealed Tall t waves and prolonged PR interval. Laboratory results revealed an elevated serum Potassium level, normal Creatinine with low Bicarbonate levels. His medications include Glimepiride+Metformin combination for his diabetes along with Telmisartan+Amlodepine combination for hypertension.  Which finding is expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Urine ph < 5.5

The patient has Type 4 RTA (Also called Hyperkalemic RTA). Telmisartan (ARB) causes Aldosterone defect leading to defect in eNa+C which decrease both H+ and K+ secretion into the urine. This leads to NAGMA with high Urinary Anion gap due to lower urinary Chloride levels. However, the defect in acidification is mild and the urinary ph is < 5.5.

questions.text:
A 28 year old actress presented with a four week history of breathlessness. She had returned from Himalayan trekking six weeks ago. She had no cough but had intermittent chest tightness and had been started on Salbutamol with no improvement. Results showed a normal Chest X-ray, ECG and spirometry. Oxygen saturations were 99% on air at rest and after walking up a flight of stairs. Her ABG Shows Ph ; 7.50 , Pao2 : 94 mmhg , Paco2 : 28 mmhg , HCO3- : 20 meq /L . 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hyperventilation Syndrome

The ABG show a respiratory alkalosis with low paCO2 produced by alveolar hyperventilation and low bicarbonate suggesting renal compensation and therefore the hyperventilation may be longstanding. Hyperventilation syndrome is a diagnosis of exclusion and the normal investigations and in particular the lack of fall in oxygenation on exertion suggests the other diagnosis are unlikely

questions.text: Very slow, irregular, twisting movement, one movement perpetually blending with another is called:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Athetosis. 

Involuntary movements indicate defect of Basal Ganglia Complex. The common ones are:

A. Athetosis is usually due to defect in the Putamen. It is slow sinuous writhing movement resembling a CRAWLING movement of distal upper limb where one movement blend with another.

B. Chorea usually indicates defect of Caudate Nucleus and described as Quasi-purposive (Semi-purposive) movements.

C. Hemiballismus indicates defect of Subthalamic Nucleus and is flinging, violent movement involving proximal joints and can lead to serious accidents/injury.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is being treated for diabetic coma in the intensive care unit. The patient has been receiving total parenteral feeding for the past three days. Today on morning rounds, the provider notices that he is less responsive than usual and suspects refeeding syndrome. Lab results will most likely show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Refeeding syndrome

•	Hypophosphatemia is considered a hallmark of refeeding syndrome (RS) and is used as a surrogate marker.

•	In one prospective cohort study of a heterogeneous group of ICU patients starved for at least 48 hours. Hypophosphatemia was reported in 34% of patients an average of 1.9 days after feeding was restarted. Reported incidences of RS range from 0.43% to 18% in hospitalized patients.

•	Other electrolyte irregularities may also include but are not limited to decreased amounts of magnesium, potassium, and thiamine.

•	Hypoalbuminemia, hyponatremia, and hypocalcemia are not associated with RS.

•	With rising glucose levels, the body produces a countermeasure of insulin levels, which drives phosphorus and potassium intracellularly, causing a decrease in the amount of available extracellular potassium or hypokalemia.  

•	Hypokalemia may lead to cardiac arrhythmias or weakness, fatigue, paralysis, hypoventilation and respiratory distress, and metabolic alkalosis. In refeeding syndrome, attempts to correct potassium are often difficult to achieve. In order to correct the potassium, the magnesium must be checked and corrected as well in order for the potassium to be corrected.

•	Hypomagnesemia is also observed in refeeding syndrome (RS). However, its mechanism of involvement in RS is less understood. Hypomagnesemia may be implicated in RS due to its effect on other electrolyte levels. Notably, decreased magnesium levels can exacerbate hypokalemia and increase renal potassium wasting. Several enzymes utilized in ATP production are also dependent on magnesium as well. Changes in magnesium levels can also manifest in neuromuscular symptoms, including ataxia, vertigo, convulsions, paresthesia, and depression in RS patients.

questions.text: This image is suggestive of?
questions.solution:

Lightning is a powerful natural electrostatic discharge produced during a thunderstorm. The electric current passing through the discharge channels is direct with a potential of 1000 million volts or more.

•    Surveillance of high-risk patients:

♦  BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation, or untested first-degree relative of known carrier

♦  Chest radiation between age 10–30 years for Hodgkin's lymphoma

♦  Lifetime risk of 20–25% as determine by statistical risk assessment models such as BRCAPRO or Gail

♦  Oher genetic mutations, including p53 and Cowden

Breast MRI should not be used instead of mammography; it is a complementary study to other breast imaging modalities.

questions.text: Which of the following IS NOT a contra-indication for brachytherapy for carcinoma prostate?

Brachytherapy for prostate can be HDR (High dose radiotherapy) or LDR (Low dose radiotherapy). In HRD a temporary implant is placed in prostate which is removed after for 10-20 mins while in LRD a permanent implant in kept in prostate

LDR procedures use low-energy radiation sources, most commonly iodine 125 (125I) or palladium 103 (103Pd). 

Iridium 192 (192Ir), the most common HDR brachytherapy source  

Indication for brachytherapy are 

•	PSA level is between 10 and 20 ng/ml, or

•	Gleason score is < 7, or

•	Stage of cancer is < T2b.

•	Prostate volume of approximately 20-60 cc 

EBRT is preferred if

•	PSA level is higher than 20 ng/ml, or

•	Gleason score is 8, 9 or 10, or

•	Stage of your cancer is T2c, T3 or T4.

•	Brachytherapy is not a good treatment option for patients with significant baseline obstructive uropathy. 

•	Exclude patients with a baseline American Urologic Association (AUA) symptom score > 15 if already on medication, or > 20 if previously untreated for obstructive symptoms

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true regarding local anesthetic systemic toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CARDIOVASCULAR TOXICITY OF LOCAL ANESTHETICS:

•	MAIN MECHANISM: block of cardiac Na+ channels leading to negative inotropy (hypotension) and arrythmias

•	CVS toxicity is a severe form of toxicity because of slow rate of recovery of blocked sodium channels from bupivacaine (high potency)

•	Arrythmias that can happen are:

•	Prolonged PR interval, wide QRS complexes ultimately leading to sinus bradycardia and cardiac arrest (any rhythm)

TREATMENT

•	Drug of choice is infusion of 20% INTRALIPID solution: bolus dose: 1.5 ml/kg followed by infusion of 0.25 ml \kg\min

•	Mechanism: it increases the rate of recovery of blocked sodium channels by decreasing cardiac bupivacaine concentration.

•	Propofol although contains lipid in it , but is not recommended as a substitute for intralipid because of requirement of large amount of propofol and its hemodynamic effects.

•	No other antiarrhythmic is useful in the management of bupivacaine induced cardiac arrythmias

•	Use of lignocaine is not recommended in arrythmias due to bupivacaine.

•	2 drugs useful are adrenaline and amiodarone as per ACLS guidelines for the management of cardiac arrest

•	Later in severe cases Extra Corporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO) can be used.

questions.text: Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation is used to relieve pain. What is the mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pain is produced by the noxious stimuli perceived by specific sensory receptors called nociceptors which are there at the free nerve endings of primary afferent terminals of A delta and C fibres.

An action potential is generated at this nociceptor (transduction) which are then further carried by the A delta and C fibres towards the higher centre (transmission) and make us feel pain (perception).

Pain is a unique sensory signal as it is maximally changed on its way towards the higher cortical centres (modulation)

Some of the modulation systems are described below:

a. Endogenous pain modulation system: Endogenous opioids like endorphins, enkephalins and dynorphins act on the opioid receptors present in the dorsal horn and results in presynaptic inhibition.

b. Segmental inhibition: Local inhibition in the dorsal horn is mediated by the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters like glycine and GABA.

c. Gate control theory of pain: It states that activating the larger diameter A beta fibres leads to inhibition of pain signals transmitted via smaller diameter A delta and C fibres.

An inhibitory interneuron acts as a physiological gate which is closed by stimulation of A beta fibres.

Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS), spinal cord stimulation, peripheral nerve stimulation was established based on this principle.

d. Descending inhibitory pathways: Periaqueductal grey (PAG) and the rostral ventromedial medulla in the midbrain send descending fibres which project into the dorsal horn of the same side of tissue damage. 

These inhibitory neurons are activated by serotonin (SHT) and norepinephrine (NE). 

They send an inhibitory signal in the dorsal horn and reduce the intensity of the signal which is transmitted from first order neuron to the second order neuron.  Antidepressant medications activate this system and increase the level of SHT and NE and help in reducing the intensity of pain.

questions.text: 27-year-old patient shows extreme psychomotor agitation to the point of physical exhaustion. At times, he holds unusual, uncomfortable-looking body positions. Which of the following statement is not true about the clinical diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

This condition can’t be lethal.

(Ref : Kaplan synopsis pg 343)

Medical conditions that can cause catatonia include neurological disorders (e.g., nonconvulsive status epilepticus, and head trauma), infections (e.g., encephalitis), and metabolic disturbances (e.g., hepatic encephalopathy, hyponatremia, and hypercalcemia). Medications that can cause catatonia include corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, and antipsychotic (i.e., neuroleptic) agents. Catatonic symptoms may be seen in extreme forms of neuroleptic-induced parkinsonism or neuroleptic malignant syndrome, a rare, potentially lifethreatening disorder associated with fever, autonomic instability, impaired consciousness, and rigidity.(LETHAL CATATONIA). Benzodiazepines can provide temporary improvement in symptoms, and their use may improve patients’ ability to communicate and to care for themselves. ECT is appropriate for catatonia due to a general medical condition, especially if the catatonia is life threatening (e.g., inability to eat) or has developed into lethal (malignant) catatonia. The mechanism behind the efficacy of ECT is unknown.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to your emergency department under arrest by the local police. The patient was found naked at a busy intersection jumping up and down on top of a car. Interviewing the patient, you discover that he has not slept in 2 days because he does not feel tired. He reports hearing voices. The patient was previously hospitalized 1 year ago with auditory hallucinations, paranoia, and a normal mood. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Schizoaffective disorder.

This patient is suffering from schizoaffective disorder. Schizoaffective disorder is characterized by symptoms of schizophrenia plus mood changes such as mania or depression.

In this case, the patient is hearing voices, consistent with schizophrenia, and is experiencing a manic episode with the classic symptoms of public nudity and decreased need for sleep. Importantly, a diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder requires that the patient experience psychotic symptoms WITHOUT mood disorder for at least 2 weeks. The patient's history is consistent with this requirement.

pH is >4.5

This is a picture of pseudo-hyphae seen in candidiasis. It is a fungal infection so itching is the most common complaint. It is more common in pregnancy and COC pill users. It requires acidic medium for growth and pH is less than 4.5.

questions.text: Identify the following Mullerian anomaly?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bicornuate uterus

There is a partial fusion of two Mullerian ducts. So, it is bicornuate uterus. Since there are two cervices, it is bicornuate bicollis.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a risk factor for the following condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Multiple caesarean sections in past

Multiple vaginal deliveries will be a risk factor since there will be shearing, stretching and straining of the supports during vaginal delivery. Caesarean is not a risk factor for pelvic organ prolapse.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a cause of precocious puberty in girls?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Stein-Levinthal syndrome

Stein Levinthal syndrome is PCOS. It can cause delayed puberty or amenorrhoea but it can never cause precocious puberty. Precocious puberty is seen in tumours of CNS like hamartoma as well as in CAH and McCune Albright syndrome.

questions.text: A 47 years old lady had menorrhagia. She underwent USG. Identify the following condition:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

AUB-A

This is venetian-blinds appearance due to alternate bands of hypoechoic shadows. It is seen in adenomyosis. Investigation of choice is MRI which shows increased junctional zone >12mm. In PALM-COEIN classification, it is classified as AUB-A.

questions.text: Prophylactic craniospinal irradiation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Small cell has high chances of cerebral micro metastasis

questions.text: Identify the marked structure
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Medulla

questions.text: CT scan of thorax. Identify structure:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Labelled diagram for your reference

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct temporal sequence for the appearance of the stated radiation effect on peripheral blood components?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lymphocytopenia, granulocytopenia, thrombocytopenia, anemia

The chronological sequence over which the components of peripheral blood decline after irradiation are lymphocytes, granulocytes, platelets and erythrocytes

questions.text: Find below the contrast study and identify the investigation and possible diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Urethrography refers to the radiographic study of the urethra using iodinated contrast media and is generally carried out in males.

When the urethra is studied with instillation of contrast into the distal/anterior urethra it has been referred to as:

  • Retrograde urethrography (RUG)

When the posterior urethra is studied during micturition, this has been referred to as:

  • Voiding cystourethrography (VCUG)
  • Micturating urethrography

questions.text: A 30-hour-old boy, who has not yet passed meconium, develops abdominal distention associated with bilious vomiting. A plain radiograph of the abdomen shows distended loops of bowel with air-fluid levels. A contrast enema demonstrates a normal caliber rectum, a small caliber sigmoid, and a descending colon with an abrupt caliber transition at the splenic flexure. Which of the following medications did the mother of this infant most likely require during her pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Insulin

The patient has clinical and radiographic findings consistent with small left colon syndrome, which is most often observed in infants of diabetic mothers; therefore, the mother was most likely treated with insulin for diabetes. Small left colon syndrome is characterized by colonic obstruction involving a significant caliber reduction in the sigmoid and descending colon that is unrelated to meconium inspissation or aganglionosis. It is associated with a transient inability to pass meconium that resolves spontaneously.

choices.text: Pinkish-red macular stains of the eyelid(s)

questions.text: Which of the following findings on newborn physical examination is most often associated with congenital abnormalities?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

Single umbilical artery

The umbilical cord normally contains 2 arteries and 1 vein. A single umbilical artery is identified in 0.2–0.6% of live births. This finding is more common in small-for-gestational-age infants and twins.

Up to 30% of live-born neonates with a single umbilical artery have ≥ 1 congenital abnormalities. The most common congenital anomalies in chromosomally normal neonates involve the genitourinary, cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, and musculoskeletal systems.

questions.text:
You are called to the delivery of a preterm infant whose mother received no prenatal care. She presented to the hospital ready to deliver. By dates, the infant is 34 weeks of gestational age. In the delivery room, the baby requires intubation and mechanical ventilation. On physical examination, bulging of the abdominal wall and absence of abdominal wall musculature are noted. Ultrasound demonstrates dysplastic kidneys and severe dilatation of the bladder resulting from urinary flow obstruction.

Which of the following is the anomaly most commonly associated with this disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

Bilateral cryptorchidism

The patient has findings consistent with prune belly (Eagle-Barrett) syndrome. It occurs in 1 in 40,000 live births; 95% of those affected are male. Prune belly syndrome is associated with aplasia or hypoplasia of abdominal muscles, bilateral undescended testicles, and urinary tract anomalies. Oligohydramnios and pulmonary hypoplasia also may be associated, as well as malrotation of the bowel, musculoskeletal abnormalities, and cardiac abnormalities. Renal dysplasia is the primary renal abnormality

questions.text: Which of the following developmental reflexes can be elicited in a healthy 1-year-old child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Parachute reflex

The parachute reflex appears at 6–9 months of age and persists throughout life. It is elicited by holding the baby by the waist and tilting and thrusting him/her forward as if dropping him/her.

A normal response is abduction and extension of the arms as if to break the fall—like people who jump out of airplanes. The appearance of this reflex coincides with the child’s preparedness to stand and catch himself/herself if he/she were to fall.

questions.text:
A 2-month-old infant presents with his foster parents for an initial evaluation. Little is known about his biological mother’s medical history. She reportedly received no prenatal care and presented to the emergency department in active labor while denying previous knowledge of her pregnancy. The infant is noted to have several dysmorphic features that include arched eyebrows, hypertelorism, a short upturned nose, and shortened stubby digits with hypoplastic nails.

Which of the following was the infant most likely exposed to in utero?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Phenytoin

The patient has clinical findings most consistent with prenatal exposure to phenytoin or fetal hydantoin syndrome. Several anticonvulsant drugs have been identified as teratogens. In addition to the dysmorphic features described in the vignette, adverse effects of phenytoin on the fetus and newborn may also include orofacial clefts and cardiac (ventricular septal defects) and genitourinary defects. It has also been linked to development of neuroblastoma

choices.text: Syndactyly of the 2nd, 3rd, and 4th fingers and toes
Congenital stenosis or atresia of the external ear canals

questions.text: During a health maintenance visit a 4-month-old female is noted to have a skull deformity due to premature fusion of both coronal sutures and 1 sagittal suture. Which of the following additional findings on physical examination would indicate that this patient’s cranial abnormalities are consistent with Apert, rather than Crouzon's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Syndactyly of the 2 , 3 , and 4 fingers and toes

questions.text:
A newborn female is evaluated in the nursery. The mother had poor, late care and reports that she took warfarin during her pregnancy because of a history of a deep venous thrombosis.

The most likely physical finding for this infant is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Nasal hypoplasia

This patient has had fetal exposure to warfarin. Exposure during 6–9 weeks of gestation can cause fetal warfarin syndrome with nasal hypoplasia and stippled epiphyses.

choices.text: Clustered small white papules on the cheeks
Annular discoid lesions on the scalp and face
Papules and papulopustules, some of which have ruptured, leaving a fine scale and associated hyperpigmentation on the forehead
Indurate erythematous plaques on the shoulders and back
Blotchy erythematous macules and edematous papules on the chest

questions.text:
A 10-hour-old male is noted to have bradycardia. An ECG shows a ventricular rate of 54 beats/minute. The atrial rate varies from 90 to 110 beats/minute. The QRS morphology is normal.

Which of the following is most likely to be associated with these clinical and electrocardiographic findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Annular discoid lesions on the scalp and face

The infant has clinical and electrocardiographic findings consistent with congenital heart block. Neonatal lupus erythematosus is the most common cause of this disorder in which no impulses from the atria reach the ventricles. Cutaneous manifestations, which may be present at birth or develop within several weeks of life, include discoid lesions, periorbital erythema, annular lesions, scaly atrophic patches, and/or telangiectasia.

choices.text: Treat with hydration and pain medications.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old male is brought to the emergency department because of abdominal pain, diarrhea, bilateral knee pain with swelling, and purpuric rash on his legs. These symptoms started approximately 2 weeks after an upper respiratory infection. Workup reveals leukocytosis and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. The serum chemistry panel and urinalysis are normal.

What is the best next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Treat with hydration and pain medications.

This patient has Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP). Skin, joints, and GI tract are the most commonly involved organ systems. Most cases occur after a viral infection and resolve with conservative management. Use nonsteroidals for pain control but avoid if renal disease and significant GI disease are present. Corticosteroids have been used successfully in those with severe abdominal pain or severe scrotal swelling/edema.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is most specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Anti-double stranded DNA antibody (dsDNA ab)

The anti-dsDNA ab is highly specific for SLE.

While an elevated ESR, a positive anti-SSA [Ro] antibody and a positive ANA can be seen in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus, these tests also can be found in patients with other autoimmune diseases (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, Sjogren syndrome, scleroderma, and dermatomyositis).
